intro: Acacia nigricans, commonly known as black wattle, is a flowering plant native to Australia. It is characterized by its dark, flaky bark and slender, compound leaves. The plant produces yellow globular flower heads that bloom in spring. Acacia nigricans is a woody shrub or small tree, often found in coastal and riverine habitats. It is known for its rapid growth and ability to thrive in various soil types.

Its genus is Acacia, a large group of shrubs and trees known for their distinctive acicular leaves and often thorn-like structures. This species thrives in dry, sandy soils and is often seen in shrublands and open woodlands. It plays an important role in the local ecosystem by providing habitat and food for various wildlife. Acacia nigricans is well adapted to the arid and semi-arid climates of its native range.
